sen.j: 蘇我 安麻呂（そがのやすまろ、生没年未詳）は7世紀末頃、飛鳥時代後期の日本の貴族。
sen.e: SOGA no Yasumaro (the date of birth and death are unknown) was a noble of Japan in the late Asuka period at the end of the 7th century.
SOGA no Yasumaro (date of birth and death unknown) was a Japanese noble who lived during the late Asuka period, toward the end of the 7th century.
SOGA no Yasumaro (date of birth and death unknown) was a Japanese noble who lived during the late Asuka period, toward the end of the 7th century.

sen.j: 古代の名族・蘇我氏の出身で、父は蘇我連子、姉妹に藤原不比等正室となった蘇我娼子、子に石川石足がいる。
sen.e: SOGA no Yasumaro, who was a son of SOGA no Murajiko, a brother of SOGA no Shoshi who became a lawful wife of SOGA no Fuhito and the father of ISHIKAWA no Iwatari, was from the famous Soga clan, a noble family in ancient and medieval Japan.

A member of the Soga clan, a distinguished clan in ancient and medieval Japan, SOGA no Yasumaro was a son of SOGA no Murajiko, a brother of SOGA no Shoshi (who became a lawful wife of SOGA no Fuhito), and the father of ISHIKAWA no Iwatari.

A member of the Soga clan, a distinguished clan in ancient and medieval Japan, SOGA no Yasumaro was a son of SOGA no Murajiko, a brother of SOGA no Shoshi (who became a lawful wife of SOGA no Fuhito), and the father of ISHIKAWA no Iwatari.

sen.j: 名前は「安麻侶」「安摩侶」（『日本書紀』「天武天皇紀」上）「石川安麻呂」（『尊卑分脈』）とも書かれる。
sen.e: His name appears as "Yasumaro" in two different Chinese characters spellings in the first volume of "Chronicles of the Emperor Tenmu" of "the Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and as ISHIKAWA no Yasumaro in Sonpibunmyaku.

Two different sets of Japanese kanji (安麻侶 and 安摩侶) are used for his given name in the first volume of "Chronicles of the Emperor Tenmu" in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), and his name is given as ISHIKAWA no Yasumaro in Sonpi Bunmyaku (a text compiled in the fourteenth century that records the lineages of the aristocracy).

sen.j: 彼は、天智天皇四年（671年）、天智天皇が重体となり大海人皇子（後の天武天皇）が病床に呼ばれたときに使わされた使者であった。
sen.e: In 671, Yasumaro was dispatched as a messenger to Prince Oama (later enthroned as the Emperor Tenmu) to invite him to see the Emperor Tenchi who was critically ill in bed.
When the Emperor Tenchi was critically ill in bed, Yasumaro was dispatched as a messenger to Prince Oama (later enthroned as the Emperor Tenmu) to invite the Prince to see him.

sen.j: しかし安麻呂は以前より大海人皇子と親しくしており、「有意ひて言へ（こころえてお話なさいませ）」と大海人皇子に忠告した。
sen.e: Yasumaro, who had been close with Prince Oama, warned him and said "Think twice before you talk to the emperor".
Yasumaro, who had a close and approved relation with Prince Oama, recommended him to 'think twice before you speak words to the Emperor".

sen.j: この安麻呂の一言により、大海人皇子は天智天皇の譲位を断り、吉野に脱出することが出来たという。
sen.e: Thanks to the advice, it is said that Prince Oama was able to declined the offer from the emperor to give him the throne and managed to escape to Yoshino area.
Thanks to his advice, it is said that Prince Oama was able to take a decision to decline the Emperor's offer of abdication and escaped to Yoshino area.

sen.j: 他の蘇我氏一族である蘇我赤兄、蘇我果安らが弘文天皇側に付いたのとは対照的な行動であり、天武天皇の「命の恩人」とも言える。
sen.e: Given that other members of the Soga clan such as SOGA no Akae and SOGA no Hatayasu backed the Emperor Kobun, Yasumaro's position was very unique and you can even say that, in a sense, he saved the life of the Emperor Tenmu.

Given that other members of the Soga clan such as SOGA no Akae and SOGA no Hatayasu backed Emperor Kobun, Yasumaro's position was contrasting and it is not too exaggerated to say that he 'saved the life of Emperor Tenmu.'

sen.j: ここから、天武天皇の元で重用されてもおかしくはないと思われたが、その後全く史料に見えず、没年も未詳である。
sen.e: Although you may imagine that Yasumaro could have been given a high position by the Emperor Tenmu thanks to the contribution, strangely enough, his name does not appear in historical records after that and even the year of his death is uncertain.

Naturally, he would have been given a high position by Emperor Tenmu thanks to his contribution, however, his name is not mentioned in any of the later historical records, and even the year of his death is unknown.

sen.j: ただ『続日本紀』「天平元年8月条」には官位役職は「少納言小花下」と見え、天智3年（670年）以前の官位制に基づいた名称となっており、ここから考察するに壬申の乱後幾ばくも経たない頃に早世したと考えられる。
sen.e: In the article of the August of the first year of the Tenpyo Era of "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued), Yasumaro's official court rank was referred to as "Shonagon Shokage," which was based on the official rank system before 670, suggesting that Yasumaro untimely passed away soon after the Jinshin War.

Although his name appears in the article of August of the first year of the Tenpyo Era of "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued) as 'Shonagon Shokage,' it was a position under the official rank system effective in 670 or before, and therefore, it is probable that Yasumaro untimely passed away soon after the Jinshin War.
